story:
Hey!

My name is Cierra Bray and I’m so excited and (a little scared) to share with you a very exciting project.

I’m a 25-year-old enterpriser with a passion for storytelling and encouraging people to share their real stories.  My background is in PR, social media, events and journalism which are huge assets to this project.

My passion for this project started when I realized a lot of us are living in fear to be vulnerable, to tell our real story, share our truth and be courageous.I’ve been trying to find a platform, a community of more like-minded people but have been struggling so I thought I would create my own.

 

 

Real Talk is an online web series that showcases stories of people all around the world. True, raw, real stories that we can relate to, that we can learn from.

 

We live in a world that is strategically fake. Yet some of us are craving unfiltered, real stories from real people. We are craving to show our true colours and share our truth. To spread our wings and just be ourselves, for who we are.

 

I’ve been nurturing this project like a baby and I’m so over the-moon-about it because I know it’s a need in our society.

 

We need content that is real, impactful, authentic and positive. We need content that is actually relevant and relatable.

 

The magnitude of this project will be global because I will be travelling around the world to capture those stories of real beauty, real life, real love, real happiness and real chronicles.

 

Let me break down the project and the plan.

 

Project:

Estimating Departure: May 1, 2019

The goal is to visit 50 cities around the world and interview as many people as possible. 

Why travel you ask?

The objective of the campaign is to document real stories that are global. 

We need to hear from people in different countries and communities with different resources, values, wealth, opportunities, etc.

We are all different but we are very similar to one another. If I were to just travel around Canada there would be a huge missing piece to the whole concept of this global and impactful campaign.

Here are some of the locations I will be travelling to...

Japan, Indonesia, India, Singapore, Australia, Hawaii, California, South Carolina, Oregon, Washington, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, Colorado, Pennsylvania, Alaska, Ontario, Massachusetts, New York, British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Brazil, Peru, Argentina, Nova Scotia, Quebec, and many more. 


Perks 

The project will cost an estimated $11,111 for travel(flights, hostells, food) and marketing.

I’m also selling the majority of my belongings and picking up odd jobs to help fund this project. 

For being involved in the Real Talk Community you have the opportunity of receiving some great perks:

  • Get Real Stickers  
  •  
  • Advertising Opportunities 
  • And….  Real Talk The Book containing many stories and research that I find during my travels.

 

The Impact

We are craving to hear from real people and relate to their stories. Some of us are terrified to share our truth, to be vulnerable, to be courageous and I’m committed to change that.

We fear judgement and criticism yet we feel alone and uncomfortable keeping our story bottled inside. This campaign is going to challenge the status quo,  question everything we have learned from society and start cracking us open. The stories shared could be about anything but they will all have silver linings and a positive ending.  

 

Sometimes life hits us in the face, the journey can be tough but it’s really about what we learn and the opportunities that came from it.

This campaign is so passionate to me because I want to help ignite people to start being vulnerable, courageous and activating their true self.

 

Risks & Challenges

This campaign could be risky in the eyes of potential investors but I see it as an opportunity that no one is grabbing. I see a lot of potential with this campaign.

With anything exciting, new and authentic, there are risks and challenges. I’m prepared for them and if anyone can execute this campaign it's me. I’m extremely resourceful and I have a way of empowering people to share their stories.

 

I have executed an event called YQG Talks that has showcased over 50 speakers in the last 2 years, I have mentored youth, worked with coaches and mentors, I have executed and hosted a summit with over 75 involved people.

This campaign is going to be amazing.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t help fund this project, you can help by sharing this campaign to your friends and family.

story:
Who We Are & What We Want to Do

We're an independent student production shooting "Recon", a character-driven, dramedy web series about a group of queer college freshmen and their attempts to balance their personal lives and relationships-- while training to be spies. Our team is filled with interesting, diverse, and exciting voices coming primarily from the University of Southern California's School of Cinematic Arts.

From figuring out social etiquette, navigating the diplomacy of her new deadly roommate, and Netflix and (actual) chill to taking down a huge government conspiracy, the show explores the lives of five queer spies in training as they begin to truly figure out who they are in their big scary world.

Wait-- huge government conspiracy? Set at the ancient and mysterious Academy, the show follows Ava, a skilled hacker from the Midwest who’s finally able to come out and make friends at her new school. While she’s able to make friends quickly, everything falls apart when she finds out that her entire life is being recorded and posted online in neatly edited, five- to ten-minute episodes, and her friends believe she's been making them. With a bit of Community, a bit of James Bond, and a lot of queer characters, "Recon" is a unique and exciting show with positive vibes. 


Our goal is to provide quality content about diverse characters who also happen to be queer. The sad truth is, there is still not nearly enough queer content out there in the entertainment world, but what little there is has had profound effects on queer youth, allowing them to identify with characters and feel represented. The mission of "Recon" is to give queer people their James Bond experience, featuring characters from from various racial, ethnic, and class backgrounds. To learn more about our characters, check out our character descriptions at the bottom of the campaign!

Where Your Money Will Go

We are shooting a 21 episode first season! To cover our production costs for top-notch production design and to support our incredibly dedicated and hardworking cast and crew, we need your help! Our budget is as follows:

Everything we receive on this page will go towards building “RECON” and the world of the Academy.

What you get in return besides our undying gratitude and a literal kick-ass series are some awesome perks ranging from behind-the-scenes Snapchat access to custom Recon stickers to a custom cocktail recipe book filled with drinks inspired by each of the characters.

Thank you so much for helping "RECON" be the best show it can be and providing some much needed queer, diverse content for the entertainment world!

Our Team

The Cast

 

Ana Ming Bostwick-Singer-- Ava

Ana (she/her) is thrilled to be playing the role of Ava in RECON. Growing up in the small artsy town of Ojai, California, with her screenwriting parents, a rescued Australian shepherd named Jazz, and her grandparents, she developed her appreciation and love for the environment, animals and the arts. She’s a graduate of Sarah Lawrence College, where she studied Dance and Filmmaking. When Ana’s not acting, you'll find her gracefully dancing on silks or teaching kids and teens the joys of aerial dance, or in a studio studying acting, kickboxing, dance or yoga. She’s an avid hiker, reader, cook and gym rat, and loves spending time with family and friends.

Victoria Ortiz-- Ren

Puerto Rican actress and sword fighter, Victoria Ortiz (she/her) was influenced by the arts from the moment she was born. Raised in a household of performers, she spent many nights around dressing rooms and backstage theaters in Puerto Rico. At age 11, she began fencing, and from being just a hobby, it quickly became a professional career. She had the honor of representing Puerto Rico around the world, including the Pan-American Games in Rio ’07. After graduating High School in Puerto Rico, she took a leap of faith, hung up her mask and sword, and moved to Los Angeles to begin her studies at The American Academy of Dramatic Arts. Promptly after graduating she came out to the world! Since then, she’s had the pleasure representing Latinx Queers and working on several groundbreaking LGBTQ projects, including the Award Winning short “Vámonos,” Amazon’s “Transparent,” Freeform’s “The Fosters,” MACRO’s “Gente-fied,” and Rachael Cantu’s “You’re The Most”. She’s currently working on her close up magic skills for the upcoming short “Muscle Memory” directed by award winning director Carly Usdin. She’s also really excited to take on the role of “Ren” and fulfill a lifelong dream of being in a Spy school. Follow her LA adventures on Instagram: @Puertoricaninja.

KatieMichal Pullen-- Riley

KatieMichal Pullen (she/her) is an animal-loving boxer and queer actor from Reno, Nevada. She most recently starred in the official music video for Kelly Clarkson's new song "I Don't Think About You." You can find the video at https://bit.ly/2GfnCyR and KatieMichal on Instagram at @katiemichalpullen.

Joré Aaron-- Taylor

A Los Angeles native, Joré (she/her) knew that returning home would have its difficulties. She had finally found her passion in life and her artistic voice in a far-off land with far less air pollution called Santa Barbara. Soon after such fantastic discoveries, Joré had to transition out of her comfort zone and work hard to stay connected to her craft, push the boundaries of her vulnerability in order to share it, and support its growth so that it would become stronger and more refined every day. Having accomplished much as a stage actor in past years in Santa Barbara, Joré is currently focused on making her transition into film and television smooth and successful, as well as developing her own projects in order to create opportunities for collaboration with other artists. She is on the constant search for stories that uplift, challenge, and comment on the world of today in a necessary manner, and is thrilled to be a part of RECON, as it does exactly that!

Meredith "Kat" Wells-- Jones

Meredith “Kat” Wells (she/her) is a filmmaker and actress currently studying at the University of Southern California’s Cinematic Arts School as a Film Production major. Before attending university, Meredith was in several feature films as both animated voices (Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron, Flushed Away) and live action appearances (Time Machine, Mars Needs Moms). She’s also acted in multiple short films and music videos, both a part of her school and outside of. Meredith works predominantly as a paid makeup artist on USC projects and non school productions, while also taking on many other roles behind the camera ranging from Producer to Production Designer. To see more of her work, visit her website meredithkatwells.weebly.com or her Instagram @arttrash_kat.

The Crew

Emma Drewry-- Showrunner

Emma Drewry (she/her) is a queer filmmaker and Cinema and Media Studies major at the University of Southern California, where she found her passion for transmedia and producing. With English teachers for parents, she grew up reading YA novels voraciously, including fantasy novels, romance novels, and of course, spy school novels. With Recon, she's finally able to live out her childhood dream of attending spy school and pursue her passion for creating stories for people who don't get to see themselves on screen.

Christa Troester-- Co-Executive Producer

Christa Troester (she/her) is a sophomore at the University of Southern California where she is majoring in Film and Television Production-- and French! Having grown in multiple countries across Africa, her diverse identity has made her particularly interested in film that is used to create empathy in the pursuit of international and intersectional equality, especially to showcase stories that are not usually in the spotlight. She is incredibly honored and excited to be an Executive Producer for Recon!

Justice Schiappa-- Supervising Producer, Writer

Justice Schiappa (he/him) is a queer aspiring filmmaker and actor studying Writing for Screen and Television at USC. A theater kid since a young age, Justice has a passion for performance and appreciation for all parts of the creative process including directing, writing, and costume design. Enjoying long walks to the fridge at 2am while discussing what’s out there among the stars, Justice is so incredibly excited to be an associate producer for Recon, bringing his out-of-this-world ideas a little closer to home.

Kate Allanach-- Associate Producer, Writer

Kate Allanach (she/her) is a queer, intersectional activist and filmmaker currently studying Film and Television Production at USC. Kate is the creator of the Fallen Justice webseries, a huge sci-fi nerd, and an associate producer for Recon!

Ursula Collins-Laine-- Assistant Director

Ursula (she/her) is a sophomore at USC double majoring in Cinema and Media Studies and East Asian Area Studies. She is really excited to be working with this wonderful group of people to make the vision of "RECON" into reality as the assistant director. Outside of film projects, Ursula enjoys juggling, unicycling, watching Korean reality shows, and debating various film theories and globalization with friends. Her dream job is to produce epic reality game shows for television.

Amanda Liaw-- Production Designer

As a film student at the University of Southern California, Amanda Liaw (she/her) is currently most interested in exploring how shapes, linework, and texture can inform the reading of filmic work. She is excited to develop these ideas in "RECON" and contribute to a work that is pushing boundaries with its very existence. Elsewhere, she enjoys drumming, pole dancing, and working towards building sustainable housing.

Hal Pan-- Graphic Designer, Writer

Hal (they/them) is a nonbinary Chinese-American bean studying Arts, Technology, and the Business of Innovation at USC with a minor in Animation set to graduate in spring of 2020. They are stoked to be working on the visual design of "RECON" and to have contributed as a writer. They are interested in using visual media to increase net empathy in the world by bringing less heard stories to life, and would prefer to perish than to give up animated movies and television (anime included).

Haley Hudkins-- Editor

Haley Hudkins (she/her) is part of USC’s class of 2020 where she is studying Film and Television Production. As an avid nerd, she grew up nurturing strong interests in theatre, writing, and comic books, which have all led her to be the filmmaker she is today. Diversity and inclusion in the film industry is very important to her, which is why she is so excited to be Editor for a web series as inclusive as Recon!

Victoria Perez-- associate producer

Victoria Perez (she/her) is a queer, Texas-based photographer and aspiring filmmaker majoring in Cinema and Media Studies at the University of Southern California. With a minor in Chicano-American Studies, she hopes to bring the Latin-American experience to the silver screen and increase minority representation in the film industry.

 

Characters 

AVA is from a small, rural town in the midwest. Which was...a nightmare. Ava’s so happy to finally be out on her own, though nothing could prepare her for navigating life at the Academy. Between learning how to embrace her queerness and how to make friends, this anxious, unassuming, and sensitive girl is about to have the ride of her life. A goofy girl at heart, Ava drowns herself in her work to avoid inner turmoil and insecurities, but is prone to losing her logic when her emotions become too much to handle and cloud her vision. A child prodigy in computing, it was Ava’s hacking abilities that put her on the Academy’s watch-list, and eventually led to her recruitment.

Outside of her ingrained dedication to academics, she’s driven by empathy and a powerful sense of right and wrong, but finds her sense of self and morality are immature and untested. Despite this, she tries her best to succeed, take care of her friends, and do no wrong.

Over the course of the series, Ava develops romantic feelings for Ren, and melds her friend group together by complete accident. Everything seems to be going great, but when she discovers her entire life is being filmed and posted online, and her friends are torn away from her, Ava must come face to face with her childhood fear of rejection.

 

REN is another new recruit at the Academy, specializing in the field agent track. Ren was raised born in Chicago to accepting teaching parents who never questioned their child’s queerness, helping Ren establish themselves every step of the way. Ren never really “came out”-- it was just an accepted state of being for them and their family... Ren liked hot people and hot people liked Ren. And they didn't have a gender.

Casual and confidently queer, Ren is relaxed and nonchalant about almost everything.  Ren acts as a happy, casual foil to an anxious Ava, who they befriend during orientation at the Academy. However, despite their self-assuredness, their emotional maturity has some blind spots, including a complete inability to realize that their best friend Ava is developing feelings for them...or that they’re developing them back.

Although they’re training to be a field agent, their empathetic side comes out as they realize the implications of their violent training and the amoral things the spy world has to offer. Things Ren may be forced to do. While their moral crisis plays out, so does the revelation that Ava’s life is being broadcasted online, throwing their life—and relationship with Ava—into chaos.

 

RILEY is the human embodiment of a bubble. She’s incredibly friendly and determined, loyal to her friends until the very end. Though, Riley’s path to the Academy was one ripe with tragedy. Riley is a legacy who didn’t know it: born to two spies, her parents kept her in the dark about their true profession in order to give her a normal childhood. This plan was ruined, however, when both died in the field, leaving 12-year-old Riley to be taken in by two other spies—Taylor’s parents.

Although Riley managed to maintain her chipper attitude and energetic personality, her parents’ secret life and subsequent death left her with serious scars and heavy-duty trust issues. Still, she developed a strong bond with the slightly older Taylor, who helped her adjust to her new reality and quickly became a confident and protector… and then something more.

Now training to go into the world of espionage—but not a field agent—Riley is overly enthusiastic and incredibly ready to take on her freshman year. A polyglot prodigy, Riley is invasive in several languages, using her interpersonal skills to cause others to reveal-all. First on her agenda is to make new friends, which includes Ava, who she targets for friendship as soon as she lays eyes on her.

While their friendship is fast (due to Riley’s slightly invasive but well-meaning “bonding” questions), their fallout is faster. When she sees herself online as part of “Ava’s” show, she becomes furious at Ava’s supposed betrayal, which forces Ava to learn how to mend a friendship.

 

TAYLOR, a sophomore already accustomed to the espionage game of the Academy is quieter and much more composed than her partner-in-crime Riley. Taylor is a straight-laced and high-achieving legacy who serves as a protector, and for some, eventually more than that. She’s introspective and a bit anxious, but much more in control of her emotions and identity. Serving as an orientation advisor, journalist for the school newspaper, and an active member of several clubs while pursuing her forensics degree (with honors), Taylor is easily at the top of the sophomore class. And everyone knows it. Her wit is deadly, as is her attention to detail.

Riley, however, is Taylor’s one point of weakness: protective to a fault and easily jealous when it comes to the object of her affections, she struggles to overcome her jealousy over Riley’s intense interest in and growing bond with Ava. When Riley splits from Ava, so does Taylor.

Taylor’s parents are similarly involved in the school, as minor donors and active alumni, they participate frequently in activities for both alumni and parents. Thus, the pressure is on for Taylor to be at the top of her game, but sometimes that means she has to take some time out to play games.

 

JONES is fighter who could kill you with the sharpness of her eyeliner. Or her eyeliner pencil, whichever is more convenient for her. Jones is a badass legacy student training to be a field agent, although she may be harder to best in a fight—or in an interrogation room—than most professionals.

Jones is anything but an ordinary legacy. She descends from a legendary line of high-powered, highly dangerous spies and governmental officials who disowned her mother after she married Jones’s father. Happiness was short-lived for the Jones family as during her childhood, Jones’ father was murdered her mother’s side of the family. She honors his legacy by going by his surname.

Raised on the road as her mother fled from her dangerous and dysfunctional family, Jones learned how to speak multiple languages and to always be on her guard. Finally at the Academy her treacherous, wealthy grandparents help run, she’s defensive, guarded, and here to do nothing but succeed and surpass her everyone’s expectations. But Jones hits a bit of a bump in the road when it comes to making friends. While she initially rejects any attempts at Ava’s or her friends’ attempts to befriend her in favor of silence and polishing knives, she eventually bonds with Ava when the revelation of the recordings comes out—and nothing is ever the same again.

Thank you so much for reading our story, and please like, share, and donate if you can!

Justice Schiappa (he/him) is a queer aspiring filmmaker and actor studying Writing for Screen and Television at USC. A theater kid since a young age, Justice has a passion for performance and appreciation for all parts of the creative process including directing, writing, and costume design. Enjoying long walks to the fridge at 2am while discussing what’s out there among the stars, Justice is so incredibly excited to be an associate producer for Recon, bringing his out-of-this-world ideas a little closer to home.
Kate Allanach-- Associate Producer, Writer

Kate Allanach (she/her) is a queer, intersectional activist and filmmaker currently studying Film and Television Production at USC. Kate is the creator of the Fallen Justice webseries, a huge sci-fi nerd, and an associate producer for Recon!
Ursula Collins-Laine-- Assistant Director

Ursula (she/her) is a sophomore at USC double majoring in Cinema and Media Studies and East Asian Area Studies. She is really excited to be working with this wonderful group of people to make the vision of "RECON" into reality as the assistant director. Outside of film projects, Ursula enjoys juggling, unicycling, watching Korean reality shows, and debating various film theories and globalization with friends. Her dream job is to produce epic reality game shows for television.
Amanda Liaw-- Production Designer

As a film student at the University of Southern California, Amanda Liaw (she/her) is currently most interested in exploring how shapes, linework, and texture can inform the reading of filmic work. She is excited to develop these ideas in "RECON" and contribute to a work that is pushing boundaries with its very existence. Elsewhere, she enjoys drumming, pole dancing, and working towards building sustainable housing.
Hal Pan-- Graphic Designer, Writer

Hal (they/them) is a nonbinary Chinese-American bean studying Arts, Technology, and the Business of Innovation at USC with a minor in Animation set to graduate in spring of 2020. They are stoked to be working on the visual design of "RECON" and to have contributed as a writer. They are interested in using visual media to increase net empathy in the world by bringing less heard stories to life, and would prefer to perish than to give up animated movies and television (anime included).
Haley Hudkins-- Editor

Haley Hudkins (she/her) is part of USC’s class of 2020 where she is studying Film and Television Production. As an avid nerd, she grew up nurturing strong interests in theatre, writing, and comic books, which have all led her to be the filmmaker she is today. Diversity and inclusion in the film industry is very important to her, which is why she is so excited to be Editor for a web series as inclusive as Recon!
Victoria Perez-- associate producer

Victoria Perez (she/her) is a queer, Texas-based photographer and aspiring filmmaker majoring in Cinema and Media Studies at the University of Southern California. With a minor in Chicano-American Studies, she hopes to bring the Latin-American experience to the silver screen and increase minority representation in the film industry.
 
Characters 
AVA is from a small, rural town in the midwest. Which was...a nightmare. Ava’s so happy to finally be out on her own, though nothing could prepare her for navigating life at the Academy. Between learning how to embrace her queerness and how to make friends, this anxious, unassuming, and sensitive girl is about to have the ride of her life. A goofy girl at heart, Ava drowns herself in her work to avoid inner turmoil and insecurities, but is prone to losing her logic when her emotions become too much to handle and cloud her vision. A child prodigy in computing, it was Ava’s hacking abilities that put her on the Academy’s watch-list, and eventually led to her recruitment.
Outside of her ingrained dedication to academics, she’s driven by empathy and a powerful sense of right and wrong, but finds her sense of self and morality are immature and untested. Despite this, she tries her best to succeed, take care of her friends, and do no wrong.
Over the course of the series, Ava develops romantic feelings for Ren, and melds her friend group together by complete accident. Everything seems to be going great, but when she discovers her entire life is being filmed and posted online, and her friends are torn away from her, Ava must come face to face with her childhood fear of rejection. REN is another new recruit at the Academy, specializing in the field agent track. Ren was raised born in Chicago to accepting teaching parents who never questioned their child’s queerness, helping Ren establish themselves every step of the way. Ren never really “came out”-- it was just an accepted state of being for them and their family... Ren liked hot people and hot people liked Ren. And they didn't have a gender.
Casual and confidently queer, Ren is relaxed and nonchalant about almost everything.  Ren acts as a happy, casual foil to an anxious Ava, who they befriend during orientation at the Academy. However, despite their self-assuredness, their emotional maturity has some blind spots, including a complete inability to realize that their best friend Ava is developing feelings for them...or that they’re developing them back.
Although they’re training to be a field agent, their empathetic side comes out as they realize the implications of their violent training and the amoral things the spy world has to offer. Things Ren may be forced to do. While their moral crisis plays out, so does the revelation that Ava’s life is being broadcasted online, throwing their life—and relationship with Ava—into chaos. RILEY is the human embodiment of a bubble. She’s incredibly friendly and determined, loyal to her friends until the very end. Though, Riley’s path to the Academy was one ripe with tragedy. Riley is a legacy who didn’t know it: born to two spies, her parents kept her in the dark about their true profession in order to give her a normal childhood. This plan was ruined, however, when both died in the field, leaving 12-year-old Riley to be taken in by two other spies—Taylor’s parents.
Although Riley managed to maintain her chipper attitude and energetic personality, her parents’ secret life and subsequent death left her with serious scars and heavy-duty trust issues. Still, she developed a strong bond with the slightly older Taylor, who helped her adjust to her new reality and quickly became a confident and protector… and then something more.
Now training to go into the world of espionage—but not a field agent—Riley is overly enthusiastic and incredibly ready to take on her freshman year. A polyglot prodigy, Riley is invasive in several languages, using her interpersonal skills to cause others to reveal-all. First on her agenda is to make new friends, which includes Ava, who she targets for friendship as soon as she lays eyes on her.
While their friendship is fast (due to Riley’s slightly invasive but well-meaning “bonding” questions), their fallout is faster. When she sees herself online as part of “Ava’s” show, she becomes furious at Ava’s supposed betrayal, which forces Ava to learn how to mend a friendship. TAYLOR, a sophomore already accustomed to the espionage game of the Academy is quieter and much more composed than her partner-in-crime Riley. Taylor is a straight-laced and high-achieving legacy who serves as a protector, and for some, eventually more than that. She’s introspective and a bit anxious, but much more in control of her emotions and identity. Serving as an orientation advisor, journalist for the school newspaper, and an active member of several clubs while pursuing her forensics degree (with honors), Taylor is easily at the top of the sophomore class. And everyone knows it. Her wit is deadly, as is her attention to detail.
Riley, however, is Taylor’s one point of weakness: protective to a fault and easily jealous when it comes to the object of her affections, she struggles to overcome her jealousy over Riley’s intense interest in and growing bond with Ava. When Riley splits from Ava, so does Taylor.
Taylor’s parents are similarly involved in the school, as minor donors and active alumni, they participate frequently in activities for both alumni and parents. Thus, the pressure is on for Taylor to be at the top of her game, but sometimes that means she has to take some time out to play games. JONES is fighter who could kill you with the sharpness of her eyeliner. Or her eyeliner pencil, whichever is more convenient for her. Jones is a badass legacy student training to be a field agent, although she may be harder to best in a fight—or in an interrogation room—than most professionals.
Jones is anything but an ordinary legacy. She descends from a legendary line of high-powered, highly dangerous spies and governmental officials who disowned her mother after she married Jones’s father. Happiness was short-lived for the Jones family as during her childhood, Jones’ father was murdered her mother’s side of the family. She honors his legacy by going by his surname.
Raised on the road as her mother fled from her dangerous and dysfunctional family, Jones learned how to speak multiple languages and to always be on her guard. Finally at the Academy her treacherous, wealthy grandparents help run, she’s defensive, guarded, and here to do nothing but succeed and surpass her everyone’s expectations. But Jones hits a bit of a bump in the road when it comes to making friends. While she initially rejects any attempts at Ava’s or her friends’ attempts to befriend her in favor of silence and polishing knives, she eventually bonds with Ava when the revelation of the recordings comes out—and nothing is ever the same again.
Thank you so much for reading our story, and please like, share, and donate if you can!

story:
Hello there! Thanks for visiting our Indiegogo page!

We are a small like-minded group of professional independent filmmakers from the Twin Cities area who are gladly taking time away from our 10,000 lakes this summer to film 6 episodes of an original comedy webseries, FEM 101. 

Please check out our gallery above for pics of the team and the actors!

IN THE BEGINNING...

We had a funny idea, and wanted to make a show.

We asked, what would happen if we throw 8 random characters (who just happen to be mostly men) in an urban community class setting in front of a small town white feminist teacher hell bent on doing away with patriarchy once and for all and teaching everyone what it really means to be a feminist.

FEM 101  was born.

Next, 5 Writers came up with 5 characters each. We whittled down the 25 potential omelette ingredients to the best 8 characters (See gallery pics above for actor and character info!)

The idea stuck in our heads more and more, and we soon completely dedicated ourselves to creating a 6 episode webseries to explore this theme and this story fully, with a high production value, so you will have the ultimate entertainment experience.

This June 16/17 and June 30/July 1, we are going to film 6  5-10 minute episodes in 4 days. How? By filming it like a comedy TV show, with multiple cameras, in one location:

The FEM 101 Classroom

BUT - An acronym for Behold the Underlying Truth

There's no doubt about it. We are trying to make a smart comedy webseries about feminism and everything that surrounds this word today. #Metoo, Intersectional Feminism, Sexism, Race and Racism, Class Struggle, the wage gap, reproductive rights, gendered poverty and violence, - is all ongoing. It's all related. Writer Nafeez Ahmed wrote in a 2015 article:"The systemic marginalization of women is integral to a 'crisis of civilization', as women are [presently being] systematically marginalized from key positions of power and decision-making processes across every spectrum of society, in every part of the world, rich or poor. They are discriminated against, institutionally and directly, in politics, in employment, in the arts, in media and in culture."

So the themes are there; the stakes, it's safe to say, are pretty high.

AND, as we moviemakers know too well, the film industry we work in has been wracked by the evils of sexism and racism and abuse, as the #metoo movement shows, and as the stats regarding the chronic under and misrepresentation of girls and women on Film and TV show. SO you can say it's a little personal too.

Yeah.

This is the truth about why we are making this show. Because women's stories and voices being heard affects us all and is bloody important. This is why, through this project, we aim to shed some honest light on this complex topic and how it affects EVERYONE across the entire race, class, sex and gender spectrum of American society today.

We are not the only artists sensing a shift and a pull to play in this feminist space.

Orphan Black actor Tatiana Masley surmises, "In the 21st century, the hero is emerging as a distinctly female force who faces a world of soul-destroying bleakness."

Erin Roberts, actor, who plays the Teacher of FEM 101, writes of our new show in her recent blog:

"Although it is a comedy, it's inspired by the continuous battle for intersectional feminism and gender equality. At the risk of sounding cheesy, the notion of art imitating life and vice versa is a thing. It is a way we feel and express ourselves, and though art is often considered entertainment, at the same time, it can also be used for teaching and raising awareness."

The FEM 101 Team is proud to have at least gender parity (50% women) both behind the camera and in front of the lens.

EVERYBODY is included in, and invited to, our webseries and our exploration of feminism. So all individuals from all communities everywhere, welcome!

How You Can Help

There's no question about it: You can help us make this webseries come to life. We appreciate entirely, beyond words and perk rewards, your financial support for our endeavor. Filmmaking is the most expensive art on earth, and while most of us have been making films for decades and are privileged to have access to expensive equipment...

we do need

your help

securing $5,000.

  • Why do we need $5,000? While EACH and every one of us are working pro bono to create this project because it's just so darn' funny and we love working with each other and we are so eager to bring this story and these characters to life...we do need help financially to take care of some small but important needs. Specifically:
  • $2000 to pay for craft services (film industry term for food and beverages) to keep our fantastic crew and ensemble cast well-nourished for the four days it will take to get the webseries filmed and in the can.
  • $3000 to pay our 12 actors a small daily stipend for their time and artistic contributions, without which we would have. absolutely. nothing. Did you see the talent up there in the gallery?!
  • $500 to pay for Art Supplies, Special Props and Wardrobe (Hey, pussyhats are expensive to make!)

You won’t regret helping us out!

As well as getting to see our exciting final product, donors will be treated to a selection of very special perks. These include everything from complete season digital downloads to FEM 101  T-shirts to Executive Producer Credits. 

​If we don't reach our entire goal, we will be able to retain what we do accumulate from our backers. So stay strong.

The Impact

FEMINISM and its related issues affects everybody. Everyone has had a mother, a grandmother, or knows a woman, or a girl. Your contribution will be a small yet very important part of bringing this webseries to life. In doing so, we together have the chance  -- even just the tiniest little bit -- to make the world, for EVERYBODY, especially our women and girls and grandmas, a better place.

We change the narrative one story at a time.

Please contribute to our campaign! We are grateful for all donations, big or small.

Other Ways You Can Help

We do understand that not everyone is in a position to give money. If that’s the case for you, that’s ok! Anything you can do to help would be greatly appreciated. Please consider sharing our campaign, following us on social media, and of course watching FEM 101 when it’s released. :)

Whether you give $0, $10, or $1000, we know and love that you too support women's rights, intersectional feminism, and the arts community.

Thank you!

The FEM 101 Team

story:
Short Summary

Hi my name is Adrian Alexander! I'm a native New Yorker with Venezuelan background and also currently a senior at Marymount Manhattan College in the Upper East Side of NYC. Finishing my last year studying Digital Media & Video Production. This has been a passion project of mine since I was a junior in high school and was the main reason for my transition from studying theatre to now film.

The reason I left theatre was due to the lack of roles for Latinx actors, like myself. I grew up with a heavy consumption and influence of tv and movies. The only thing that was wrong with that was that it ruined the way I saw myself because of how the portrayal of Latin actors were making us seem, things like being low class, becoming a maid, drug addict/dealer, and uneducated (being a kid, I didn't know the difference) I went as far as avoiding the sun to not get tanner and even stopped myself from speaking Spanish at home. It took a lot of years for me to rewire my brain to not see myself negatively which in fact I'm still working on!

My mission with pursuing film has always remained the same; create better roles for latin actors, cast them and myself, and make more films! This project is going to be one of the biggest projects I've ever worked on which is why I'm reaching out to YOU, the contributors and seeking funding to change the perspective of how we're viewed in modern American TV now. A lot of shows are out of date being so this generation of latin actors are first, second, or even third generation at this point and we've achieved the American dream! Now let's bring this to actual American Television and start changing what network executives are deciding to make and show them this is something that WILL SUCCEED AND HASN'T BEEN MADE!

 

What We Need & What You Get

ALL contributors will receive a private viewing link to the pilot in May 2019!  

(Public viewing will be in Fall 2019 after Film Festivals and other Summer screenings)

Funding will go towards developing a great pilot episode. Luckily the Konnect 212 team has an extensive network of people already in the industry who are willing to help us out by giving us great deals. The budget breakdown below are 'in-kind' prices which would cost us more if we didn't have the connections and their support. We have gotten great deals on these services to cover the basics needs in each department which is vital to making a high-quality pilot! 

Budget Breakdown

Camera - $1,850

Stabilizer - $1,120

Set Rentals - $1,860

Food & Craft Services - $980

General Expenses - $800

Festival Entries - $620

Equipment Transportation - $425

Promotions & Advertising - $550

Marketing Materials - $485

Set Design & Props - $425

Hair & Makeup Artist - $385

5% Indiegogo Fee - $500

Grand Total - $10,000 

I've been on all kinds of film sets, from high productions like BET Network to even low budget student films that have little to nothing.  From a production standpoint, money makes a worlds difference. It’s hard enough to be on set all day (sometimes 12 hours+) and then being starved, and/or in freezing weather... It can help to get the cast and crew food, hand warmers, and even just a place to sit. 

But as long as the film gets made right?… Wrong! In post I’d find that not only the sound and film quality is awful but it’s not even enjoyable to watch... Which hurts a lot when you and everyone who helped invested a lot of time and only wanted the best. 

I don't want any of this to happen. This story is too personal and too important to me, and has been in the works for over 5 years now! I also want to give the cast and crew the best resources possible so that they only have to worry about one thing: their art. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Production can come with a lot of unexpected hiccups, but having four years of experience in producing, directing, and starring in films and also organizing events; with the funds to back my management skills, I feel confident in the shoot being a total success. 

With the support of a crew also well-equipped in film production and time management, I have a team behind me that will ensure Konnect 212 achieves its goal. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the funds to contribute but you'd still like to help, there are other ways:

  1. Spread the news!

  2. Share the link with friends & family
  3. Follow us on social media @Konnect212
  4. If you can provide basic necessities like food, snacks, water - these are vital!
  5. For any questions or inquiries regarding budget, reach out to me via e-mail: Konnect212@gmail.com

 

Plan of ACTION!

We will be shooting this pilot in the beginning of February in the Lower East Side of NYC. 

Run-time is estimated to be about 12 minutes.

Post-Production will take roughly 3 months, but once that's finished, the pilot will be screened in selected NYC theaters starting May 2019 and submitted to festivals around the world!

We will be sending private viewing links to our contributors, don’t worry! 

Upon its success, I hope to acquire a Network to pick up the series and produce it on an even larger scale, where we can really start making the impact towards millions of viewers. 

You can keep up with updates on the series via Facebook, Instagram, & Youtube - @Konnect212

Thank you SO much for hearing me out! - We hope you join the Konnect 212 team on this wonderful adventure! 

Sincerely,

Adrian Alexander

 Plan of ACTION!We will be shooting this pilot in the beginning of February in the Lower East Side of NYC. Run-time is estimated to be about 12 minutes.Post-Production will take roughly 3 months, but once that's finished, the pilot will be screened in selected NYC theaters starting May 2019 and submitted to festivals around the world!We will be sending private viewing links to our contributors, don’t worry! Upon its success, I hope to acquire a Network to pick up the series and produce it on an even larger scale, where we can really start making the impact towards millions of viewers. You can keep up with updates on the series via Facebook, Instagram, & Youtube - @Konnect212Thank you SO much for hearing me out! - We hope you join the Konnect 212 team on this wonderful adventure! Sincerely,Adrian Alexander

story:
BALLS is a sketch comedy show that shatters all preconceived conceptions of what a sketch comedy show is. BALLS' hyper-ironic and absurd tone tackles everyone's favourite film and TV cliches and twists them into an original and belly-hurting experience. From an apple farmer waging war with zombie doctors to a coming of age indie trailer featuring a halfwitted adolescent and his cuckoo imaginary friend, BALLS will bring you to tears and then some!

 

When the last apple is sold from Mickey Danish’s Danish Farms and Orchary, the grumbling old fart is forced to confront an ancient curse with his hillbilly family and interns dressed like Apples. Can an apple really keep the doctor away? 

 

An insecure father put it all on the line when his new fun loving son-in-law embarrasses him in  game of Monopoly. 

Two sleazy salesmen are thrown into shark infested waters when a customer is actually interested in the religion they are selling. They have no choice but to get their story straight about their good friend Jesus or risk missing out on their only sale ever. 

This parody trailer follows a boy and his imaginary friend as they face adversity over their friendship. This trailer satirizes classic indie movie cliches and tropes while throwing in some curveballs itself!

In fourth year, Ryerson Media Production students form groups of 7 and work with industry professionals to plan and create a professional production of their choice, with only a small handful of projects getting the greenlight. Our team chose to make a television pilot and was selected to be created.

 

The BALLS team is composed of Sasha “BJ” Bjelic, Chris “Duck” Romualdo, Amit “Mito” Bhattacharjee, Andrew “Opes” Opar, Alex “Rez” Pires, and Jacob “Erx” Erxleben. Long time friends Alex, Jacob, and Andrew met Sasha, Amit, and Chris individually in first year and we quickly bonded due to our absurd and satirical humour. 

 

We decided then and there to make our thesis film together and over the years refined our skills to reach the point we are now. Initially being called The Dan Leckie Boys, our team made short skits for our classes, which all received critical acclaim. As our skills grew, we rebranded to “Leviathan Productions” and began to work on BALLS with the help of accomplished mentor Allan Novak. 

 

 

Despite what you may think, The BALLS team are only mere mortals. They could never accomplish their ambitious vision by themselves, and received mentorship from several successful writers and producers in the Canadian Comedy industry. Firstly, Canadian Comedy producer, director and editor Allan Novak,  who helped the group organize and create the entire pre-production bible to guide the production process. Alongside Allan, the boys met up with Canadian comedic legends Dan Redican, Tim Burns and Paul Chato. These three wise men helped the writers of Balls improve upon their existing scripts, and offered wisdom and insight on the industry.

We’ve been shooting sketches in our friends’ apartments with anything we could find around the house for years. While we fondly remember those times, it’s important to us that we move forward and show the world what we can do with a bit of support. The majority of our budget will go towards location rentals and set design—props, wardrobe, locations, and anything else that will immerse our audience in the world of BALLS. 

 

Our next largest expense is feeding the cast and crew. We’ve been lucky enough to cultivate a team that believes in BALLS as much as we do—but while we appreciate their help and dedication, we also appreciate the fact that they’re volunteering their time and energy to bring our dreams to life. We couldn’t possibly thank our team members enough, but that won’t stop us from trying.

The rest of our budget will be distributed among miscellaneous expenses: equipment rentals, transportation, promotion and distribution, etc. They may not be the most exciting portions of the budget, but without a strong foundation and a clear idea of the logistics, we’re just a group of kids with a lot of ideas and a camera.

We need your help to create a sketch comedy show of this quality and uniqueness. Our Indiegogo community will be part of the filmmaking process from the very beginning; funding our vision and joining forces with a new generation of comedians and filmmakers.

Well apart from our exciting personalized rewards, you will be helping a great group of individuals achieve their dream, and eventually be able to watch some of the funniest sketches of all time. Your donations will be helping support students and local productions that otherwise could not exist. Just trust us, don’t overthink it. It’s a really good investment. 

The most significant risk to any production is the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. To protect the health and well-being of all cast and crew members, we have updated our safety plan to require  Safe Sets COVID-19 Certification to minimize any risk of COVID transmission. Furthermore, we will provide hand sanitizer at shoots, require masks (with the exception of actors on camera), and have reworked scripts and call sheets in order to reduce the number of people on set and facilitate social distancing.

The other (less topical) challenge we face is funding. Aside from a literal apocalypse (which wouldn’t surprise any of us at this point), nothing will stop us from creating BALLS. If worse comes to worst and we don’t meet our funding goal, we’ll just revise the financial plan, stop feeding our PAs, and try again. We believe in this project, and if we only have room in the budget to film in an abandoned forest on a flip phone, then we’ll make the best found-footage sketch comedy show the world has ever seen (but also please help us to not do that).
